author: @montycobra
text: Additionally, the USSR raised the standard of living even in capitalist countries, where the ruling class had to make concessions to prevent revolts. Look at the working hours dropping after 1917. The USSR created a world standard to measure the quality of life everywhere, and now it's gone.

‚Äã@Timonta2 the thing with truth is that you don't have to believe it -- you can study it and actually learn the truth of it. I did that. 

Think of a fact that would prove your assumptions right or wrong, and search for it. Find what all the sides said about it and check those facts. Find out who is lying to you, but be honest with yourself if your assumptions are proven wrong.

author: @waitingformyman9317
text: Nasser's Egypt was great as anti-imperialists but they weren't Marxists at all, very much "progressive bourgeois" and blocked communist movements frequently. Their alliance with the USSR was strategic but they had limitations due to, well, being governed by progressive bourgeoisie. Of course, once said bourgeois had done what they wanted to do in terms of development, there was no need to go further, which really expressed itself in the leadership of Sadat and especially Mubarak. That's what the Non-Aligned Movement was ultimately destined for. Still better than Saddam, who was a convenient tool for the US until he no longer had any use for them.

author: @YarmanZJ
text: I am from Cuba, come visit and enjoy our 6 hours of eletricity a day if you get lucky! Communism is so great.

replies.author: @tymanung
replies.text: Th re are capitalist countries where many people do not have any electricity.

replies.author: @YarmanZJ
replies.text: @tymanungMind you, this is in our capital city. Our rural areas are lucky to get any electricity at all. We gotta wait a week before we receive food, and even then it‚Äôs very little, the rationing system for Cuba sucks. That‚Äôs how miserable things are in here. Our electric system is so outdated but it would cost a bunch of money they Cuba does not have to change it. Also we get forcefully endoctronized from the moment we get into kindergarten.

replies.author: @67mohammedjunaid
replies.text: @YarmanZJhow was your life quality under Batista just compare

replies.author: @YarmanZJ
replies.text: @67mohammedjunaid That‚Äôs like asking me to choose between starving slowly or getting shot. neither system gave us freedom, but at least under Batista we weren‚Äôt banned from leaving the country or forced to worship the government like a god. The revolution promised dignity and progress, and 60 years later we still can‚Äôt keep the lights.

replies.author: @67mohammedjunaid
replies.text: @YarmanZJwow when Michael Parenti visited Cuba he visited a poor region and asked ‚ÄúDo you like Fidel Castro‚Äù the Cuban took him to a clinic and told ‚ÄúUnder Batista the patient would mostly die on the long way to hospital, now there are clinics everywhere‚Äù, moreover the US trade embargo is a literal genocide in Cuba. Sadly the Cuban young generation believes it‚Äôs a lie according to my Cuban comrade, he told the young generation love American rap stars and think the embargo is a government lie. Just look how Cuba flourished in 70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs

replies.author: @67mohammedjunaid
replies.text: @YarmanZJanyway just compare Cuban life quality with it‚Äôs neighbours. Under Batista 99% lived in poverty and 1% flourished

replies.author: @YarmanZJ
replies.text:
‚Å†@67mohammedjunaid I visit Cuba every two years, every year it‚Äôs worse. That‚Äôs the same narrative they teach us in school, and it falls apart when you live in Cuba bro. Sure, there are clinics but literally medicine. Hospitals exist, but they don‚Äôt have running water or proper equipment. The embargo doesn‚Äôt stop Cuba from buying food or medicine from other countries; our government simply doesn‚Äôt prioritize it.
The economy was never perfect under Batista, but comparing 1950s poverty to modern Cuba‚Äôs total collapse isn‚Äôt a victory. We went from being one of Latin America‚Äôs richest countries per capita to one where people can‚Äôt even buy basic soap.

replies.author: @YarmanZJ
replies.text: ‚Å†@67mohammedjunaidand as for the 70s and 80s ‚Äòflourishing,‚Äô that was literally Soviet money keeping Cuba alive. When it ended, the whole system fell apart, and gradually got worse. That tells you everything about how ‚Äòsuccessful‚Äô it really was
